Award.AwardTitle: IDR: Collaborative Research: Novel Photonic Materials and Devices based on Non-Hermitian Optics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to develop novel photonic devices and artificial materials-appropriately engineered to display properties not found in nature. A new approach that exploits the complex dielectric permittivity plane in its entirety will be employed. This will be achieved by judiciously controlling both absorption and gain-especially in integrated optical arrangements based on semiconductor wafers. To carry out this task, an interdisciplinary team composed of engineers, physicists, material scientists, and mathematicians with complementary skills and know-how has been assembled.

The intellectual merit of this activity is based on very recent developments in optics that make use of space-time reflection. The non-Hermitian potentials involved in such arrangements break the spatial symmetry, thus allowing a wave to distinguish left from right. This leads to non-reciprocal wave behavior in both space and time. The team will investigate: (i) non-reciprocal light propagation in linear and nonlinear non-Hermitian structures as a means to realize compact optical isolators and circulators; (ii) wavefront and energy propagation for on-chip beam deflectors; (iii) non-Hermitian absorbers and amplifiers by manipulating the propagation properties of light; and (iv) unidirectional invisibility induced by non-Hermitian gratings.

The broader impact of this work will be on educating students to drive tomorrow?s advancements in photonics. They will be trained in modeling, material growth, device fabrication, and optical characterization and through constant interactions with their peers at the partner institutions. The team will organize workshops to engage the photonics community at large in non-Hermitian optics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this proposal was to exploit the full complex permittivity plane by modulating both the real and the imaginary part of the refractive index of a photonic medium. Along this framework a new notion of space-time reflection (or PT symmetric) optics has been developed. These photonic systems are described by an effective non-Hermitian Hamiltonian and can be realized by judiciously controlling both absorption and gain within the photonic structure. We have focused in integrated optical arrangements based on semiconductor wafers and demonstrated theoretically that these structures can show novel wave transport characteristics. Specficailly we have investigated and propose:

(i) non-reciprocal light propagation in linear and nonlinear non-Hermitian photonic structures as a means to realize compact optical isolators and circulators.

(ii) wavefront and energy propagation in such non-Hermitian structures aiming to identify protocols that allow self-imaging at predefined spatial positions

(iii) devices that at specific frequencies either completely absorb or amplify the light depending on the initial arrangements of the input light.

(iv) unidirectional invisibility induced by judiciously arrangements of gain and loss mechanisms within the photonic structure. 

During the period of the grant one PhD student and two master students graduated and found a post-doctoral and PhD positions respectively.  Several undergraduate students have wrote their Honor Thesis on themes related with the grant. The grant has also supported partially the work of a post-doctoral associate. All of them have been participated in international conferences with talks and have disseminated the results of the grant to the broader scientific community. Finally during the period of the grant the PI has been involved in an outreach activity with a local elementary school.
